Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the Upper Elementary level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 150 words that follows your plan. Use a dictionary to check the meanings of any unfamiliar words.

Human aging is like a person growing older, but much slower. It happens to everyone who lives long enough. As we age, our body changes in many ways. Our skin becomes less smooth and more wrinkled. Our hair turns gray or white. We may need glasses to see things clearly. We might also need more time to recover from illnesses or injuries. Scientists study aging to understand why these changes happen and how we can stay healthy for as long as possible.

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the Upper Elementary level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 150 words that follows your plan. Use at least 7 of the 10 words provided (aging, wrinkles, shrinking, bones, skin, cells, body, strong, energy, young).

Everyone ages, that's a fact. Aging is when your body changes over time. When you're young, your body is strong, full of energy, and your skin is smooth. But as you get older, your skin starts to change. It gets wrinkles, like little lines all over your face and hands. This happens because your cells, which are like tiny workers in your body, start to work slower and don't fix things as well as they used to. Your bones also start to shrink and aren't as strong as before. This is why older people might move slower and need more rest. But even with these changes, older people can still do many things and have a lot of wisdom from all their experiences. It's important to remember that aging is a natural process and nothing to be scared of.

Human aging is a natural process that happens to everyone. As we get older, our body and mind change in many ways. Our skin may wrinkle and our hair might turn gray or fall out. We might not be as strong or fast as we used to be, and our memory might not be as sharp. This is because our cells, the tiny building blocks of our body, start to wear out and don't work as well as they used to. But don't worry, aging is a normal part of life and there are many things we can do to stay healthy and happy as we get older, like eating well, exercising, and spending time with loved ones.

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the Upper Elementary level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 150 words that follows your plan. Remember to include the 5 main points you identified in your graphic organizer.

Human aging is a natural process that happens to everyone as they grow older. As we age, our bodies change in many ways. Our skin gets wrinkles and becomes thinner. Our muscles become weaker and we may have trouble moving around like we used to. Our hearts may not pump blood as strongly as they once did, which can make us feel tired or short of breath. Our brains may not work as quickly as they used to, which can make it harder to remember things or solve problems. We also become more likely to get sick or injured as we age. However, there are things we can do to help slow down the aging process, like eating healthy foods, exercising regularly, and getting enough sleep. It's important to remember that aging is a normal part of life and that everyone goes through it at their own pace.

Human aging is the process by which people grow old and change over time. This starts from the moment we are born and continues until the end of our lives. As we age, our bodies and minds go through many changes. Some of these changes are noticeable, like how our skin wrinkles or our hair turns gray. Others happen inside our bodies, like how our bones become less strong or our hearts beat a little slower. These changes happen because our cells and tissues start to wear out and don't work as well as they used to. But don't worry, aging is a natural part of life and happens to everyone!

Text:
Step 1: Think about how to explain 'human aging' to someone reading at the Upper Elementary level.
Step 2: Select appropriate vocabulary and sentence structure.
Step 3: Write a paragraph of 150 words that follows your plan. Use the following words: aging, cells, die, skin, wrinkle, grow, grow old, shrink, sag, gray, change, time.

Aging is what happens to our bodies over time as we grow older. It starts when cells in our body stop working as well as they used to. These cells can even die, which means they stop working forever. This is why we see changes in our skin. It can wrinkle, which means it folds and gets small lines. It also sags, which means it droops and isn't as firm as before. Our hair can turn gray, which happens when the cells that make our hair color stop working. All these changes are a part of growing old.
